Study Arm #1: HU6 Dosing

Participants in this arm will receive HU6 in 3 different dosing levels: 5mg/kg, 10mg/kg, and 15mg/kg, depending on their body weight. The drug will be administered twice daily for 28 days, with a total of 420mg / day in the 5mg/kg arm, 840mg / day in the 10mg/kg arm, and 1,260mg / day in the 15 mg/kg arm. This is a total of 28 days of treatment with HU6 after a 14-day washout period after completion of the baseline diet.

The placebo comparator arm will be titled "Placebo: Matching Placebo." This arm will be similar to the Active Treatment: HU6 arm, with the exception that participants will receive matching placebo instead of the active drug, HU6. This comparator arm is necessary to allow us to evaluate the effects of HU6 against a control condition. 

Study design
=================
Randomized interventional

Inclusion criteria
=================
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Subjects, male or female, at least 18 years of age at the time of signing the informed consent (IC).
2. BMI [Body Mass Index] of at least 25 to under 40 kg/m2 (kg/m2 = weight (kg)/height (m)2).
3. Subjects with fasting glucose level of at least 110 to under 250 mg/dL (mg/dL = milligram [mg] per deciliter [dL]).
4. Subjects with ALT [Alanine Aminotransferase] level of at least 20 to under 300 IU/L (International Unit [IU] per liter [L]).
Minimum age: 18Y
Maximum age: 80Y
Gender: Both

Exclusion criteria
=================
Exclusion Criteria:
Note for exclusion criteria of NAFLD 7. Subjects with a history of chronic liver disease (Chronic Liver Disease [CLD]).
8. Subjects with a history or findings suggesting autoimmune liver disease.
9. Subjects with a history of significant alcohol intake.
Note for exclusion criteria of NAFLD 10. Subjects with a history of use of or addiction to alcohol which includes 15 units of alcohol or more per week for men and 10 units of alcohol or more per week for women for a period of at least six months. (1 unit of alcohol is equivalent to 360 mL of beer, 150 mL of wine, or 45 mL of liqueur/hard liquor.)
11. Subjects with a history of clinically significant gastrointestinal (GI) illness.
12. Subjects with a history of cirrhosis.
